No results achieved in Q1.
Q2: "Total 3 Targeted to Living Wage (National Level) (1). MoLVT issued an instruction No.058 on back pay seniority indemnity from 2019. (2). MoLVT also issued another instruction No. 057/19.KB/SNKKS on payment of seniority indemnity before 2019 (3). Ministry of Economic and Finance (MoEF) issued a circular No 003 on Tax Exception on Back Pay Seniority before and from 2019
Total 1 targeted to Social Dialogue (1). MoLVT issued Prakas No. 302K.B/Br.K.K.B.K on Shop Steward for Enterprise and Establishment (It is new and help improve labor law in case of being no CBA or MRS).
Note: Shop steward referred to a person elected as a Union representative in the workplace. Their role is to be the first contact when an employee is faced with a work-related concern or issue. Shop stewards are sometimes referred to as a Section Secretary. The focus of a shop steward is to effectively resolve an issue within the company in a way that is acceptable to both parties. He or she will generally request a meeting to discuss the issue with a supervisor or manager within the company. However, CLC legal team identified that Shop Steward can paralyze CBA and MRS at workplace because it seem everything is organized by employer including budget allocation." Q3: Total 1 target to SD (1). Ministry of Labour issued an Instruction on No.052 on adjustment to the procedure for applying the Certification as Most Representative Status (MRS) of the Trade Union.
CLC/C.CAWDU involved in the lobbied to raise all the challenges and difficulties regarding the application of MRS at meetings with the Labour Advisory Committee (LAC). CLC was actively did lobby meetings with the legal team and consulted with other law-specialized organizations especially ILO, and ACIL (American Center International Labor) to get input regarding these issues.
Total 2 targets to LW (1) Ministry of Labour issued a Notification No.024 on Schedule of Minimum Wage Negotiation in the Textile, Garment and Footwear Sector for 2020. (2) . Ministry of Labour issued a Prakas No.389 on Legal Minimum Wage 2020.
CLC/C.CAWDU is a member of LAC (Labour Advisory Committee) and the member of the National Council and National Council on Minimum Wage. We involved in the lobbied and discussion process. CLC and C.CAWDU joint very actively at the round of negotiation. This was also reached the agreement of 190 USD for minimum wage 2020.

No target achived in Q4.
But there are keys progress of this indicator so far has been transpired during 2018: for Living Wage: (1). At international level: ILO convention recommendation N0.135 on minimum wage fixing recommendation as a means of fixing wages higher than the minimum through free collective bargaining. CLC represents ITUC and playing a key role in advocating Minimum Living Wage in Cambodia. At this moment, ITUC just have specific strategy for a claim called Asian Fight for +50. The roles of CLC is to advocate to particulary Government of Cambodian and ASIAN Gobvernment in general. (2). Industry-wide collective bargaining flateform facilitated by ACT (Social dialogue at industrial level): • Industry collective bargaining is a mechanism that brings together national representatives of manufacturers and workers - namely employer associations and trade unions - to negotiate and agree wages and conditions that will apply to a whole industry sector within country. • ACT (Action, Collaboration, and Transformation) is a ground-breaking agreement between global brands and retailers and trade unions to transform the garment, textile and footwear sector and achieve living wages for workers through collective bargaining at industry level.

MW= 182$ and bi-month-pay are the national standard
Note: Prakas No. 465 MLVT/P on Minimum Wage for Workers in the Textile, Garment and Footwear Industries for 2019 was issued by the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training on 5 October 2018. Under the Prakas, starting from 1 January 2019, the minimum wage for workers in the textile, garment and footwear industries will be US$182/ month. On the probationary, workers will be paid a minimum wage of US$177/month to be increased to US$182 upon the successful completion of the probationary period. Piece-rate workers shall be paid based on the actual piece produced, if the amount is high than the minimum wage stated in the Prakas. However, if the amount is lower than the minimum wage, the employers shall add the balance to make it equivalent to the above minimum wage accordingly. All other monetary benefits for the workers shall be remain.

Total 8 Capacity Development Interventions on SD and GVB with total participants = 2276 (Male = 1125 and Female = 1151) 4 Capacity Developments on SD (Total = 333 with Male 215 and Female 118) (1) On 15 July 2020, CLC leader organized a meeting participated by CLC staff and C.CAWDU legal team. At the meeting Mr. Athorn shared the progress of Social protection through NSSF services that workers will receive pension fund. Mr. Athorn emphasized that the government fail to implement pension scheme in 2019 and CLC still keep advocate and convince the government to push for implementation in 2020. The result from legal team’s analysis illustrated that the proposed revision on labour law will negatively impact the night shift worker’s benefits, and in regard to this situation, CLC is keep effort to mobilize affiliate to advocate with the government to reconsider and to promote space for more discussion or consultation. At the meeting all department also report their progress activities, challenges and set up plan for next month. The total of 20 participants (male=14, and female= 6). (2) On 20 July 2020, the C.CAWDU team assisted workers at KINGFASTION GARMENT CO., LTD for the election event, and prepared report and submitter the application of registration to the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training (MoLVT). There were 154 participants (male=117, and female=37). At the election event, workers who participated in the event elected 4 leaders including president, vice president, and treasurer, and volunteer advisor. (3) On 24 and 25 July 2020, CLC leader conducted 2 meeting participated by local trade union leaders and affiliate federations from ELITE; Din Han Enterprise Co.,Ltd; Infong (Cambodia) Garment Co.,Ltd; Orange Manufacturing (khmer) Co.,Ltd; Koaway Sports Ltd or Koa Way; and LU THAI (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD. The meeting provided opportunity for the workers from local trade union and federations raise their concern and suggestion concerning NSSF services. On 23 September, CLC's president Ath Thorn joint the Coordination Meeting on "Improving Synergies between Social Protection. At the meeting CLC/C.CAWDU brought concerns and suggestions from the previous meeting to the National Social Security Fund (NSSF). The total participant was 50 (male=25, and 25). There were 2 specific suggestions as following: (i). Workers suggest to improve NSSF’s health care services. (ii). Workers also called on the government and NSSF start applying pension fund because the government fail to apply even the government already pledged to put it in to practice in 2019. The president of NSSF accepted all suggestion and promise to inform the possibility after they have plenary session of their board. (4) On 14 September 2020, C.CAWDU conducted conference to review labour law of Cambodia. The conference was organized at Vimean Udom Restaurant. Total participant was 109 (male=59, and female= 60) from Cambodian Tourism and Service Workers Federation (CTSWF), Farmers Association for Peace and Development (FAPD), Building and Wood Workers Trade Union Federation of Cambodia (BWTUC), Cambodian Agriculture Worker Federation (CAWF), Cambodian Transportation Worker federation (CTWF), Cambodian Industrial workers federation (CIWF), Cambodian Informal Workers Association (CIWA). CLC/C.CAWDU leaders and legal team. C.CAWDU shared the disadvantage of Labour Law of Royal of Cambodia and, Cambodian Independent Teacher Association (CITA), Cambodian Confederation of Trade Union (CCU). CLC and C.CAWDU shared the 2 significant points that contrast the LL of the Royal of Cambodia: ( i ). Legal team’s analyses on the new Prakas (Ministerial Order), which is issued by MoLVT, contrasts the labour law and it also encourages employers to avoid responsibilities in paying workers compensations as the factories closed amid the COVID-19 pandemic. (ii). National assembly, MoLVT and the government of Cambodia proposed revision on the Labour Law that harm night shift workers’ benefits (the government propose to decrease basic wage from 30 percent, so it causes Cambodia’s night-shift workers lose sleep over benefit cut. All trade union leaders attend to the conference expressed their dissatisfaction on the proposed revision and suggested their representatives especially trade union confederation representing them at national level not to join any proposed meeting that initiated by MoLVT, the government or national assembly of Cambodia to adopt the new revision. 4 Capacity Developments on GBV (Total = 304 with Male 111 and Female 193) (1) On 4 July 2020, Head of CLC Gender Committee did field visits and had meeting with woman local trade union activists and factory women. Participants were from Man Ou Garment Co., Ltd; New Star Shoes Co., Ltd, VOT, Cambodian Informal Worker, and construction workers. The total participant was 42 (male= 18, and female=24). The meeting formed a woman networker and this new network will communicate all challenge with CLC and C.CAWDU to define solution for any GBV cases at workplace. (2) On 10 July, 10 and 13 August 2020, CLC Women Committee conducted 3 days follow-up and coaching session for focal trainers from local trade union as well as Goldfame Star Enterprises (Cambodia) Limitet; Roo Hsing Garment Co.,Ltd; Meng Da Footwear Industrial Co., Ltd; APPLE APPAREL (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD; BERRY, and OLIVE factory. The coaching had a total participant = 30 participants (male=10, and female=20). The follow-up and coaching session focusing on GBV. All participants were aware of the basic concept of GBV and they were able to prepare session plan and able to apply participatory approach tools. (3) From 25 to 27July 2020, the CLC Woman Committee conducted coaching and follow up local trade union leaders from Sabrina and Top Summit factories. The total participant was 48 (male=18, female= 30). At the meeting, trade union leaders agreed together that they will encourage and promote woman to be leaders of local trade union and will provide opportunity for women to have capacity building opportunity for both internally and externally. (4) On 6 September 2020, CLC conducted a Gender Forum at Community Legal Education Center (CLEC), participated by local trade union leader, affiliate federation, gender committee and woman activists from Sabrina (Cambodia) Garment Manufacturing Corp; Dignity Knitter Limited; Goldfame Star Enterprises (Cambodia) Limitet; Roo Hsing Garment Co.,Ltd; Golden Gain Shoe Company Ltd; T & K Garment Industry Co.,Ltd; Da Rong Printing & Embroidery Co,.Ltd or Yuan Da Rong Fong (Cambodia) B Textile Co., Ltd; Haitan Garment (Cambodia) Co.,Ltd; Cambo Xin Feng Jing Garmen Co.,Ltd or Guo Tai Hua Sheng Xin Feng Jing (Cambodia) Garment Co., Ltd; Yong Sheng; E Garment Co.,Ltd; Man Ou Garment Co., Ltd.; Hung Wah (Cambodia) Garment Manufacturing Limited; Quantum Clothing (Cambodia) Ltd; Meng Da Footwear Industrial Co., Ltd; Din Han Enterprise Co.,Ltd; I-Cheng (Cambodia) Corporation; In Kyung (Cambodia) Co.,Ltd; and Graceful (Cambodia) Textiles Co.,Ltd. CLC shared experiences related to significant barriers that always curb participation of woman and young workers at local, national and international level, the 3 barriers as follow: (i). Micro level: woman and youth themselves have lack of confident and always thinking of negative about themselves. (ii). Meso: family member, husbands, and community people also do not encourage woman and also thinking of negative ways. (iii). Macro: social norm and policies. At the forum CLC encouraged young workers and woman to confront with these obstacles and mentioned that the more woman can reduce all 3 barriers, the more woman leaders and young leaders increased. Head of Gender Committee of CLC raised awareness on gender equity at workplace is important for all is not for only woman. All participants were aware of the 3 barriers by reflecting to their daily live and at workplace. The total participant was 184 (male= 65, and female= 119).

Total 7 Meetings and Consolations on LW, SD and GBV: 4 Living Wage (1) On 3 and 5 July 2020, the CLC leader participated in minimum wage negotiation facilitated by the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training (MoLVT). C.CAWDU's leader, and local trade unions leaders from Roo Hsing Garment Co.,Ltd; Man Ou Garment Co., Ltd.; and Din Han Enterprise Co.,Ltd were also attended. The meeting agreed to apply 7 criteria for minimum wage determination for 2021 which is aligned with ILO recommendation. Workers who participated the meeting suggested to MoLVT officials that the 2021 minimum wage should be 250 USD. MoLVT accepted the suggestions from the workers and they expressed that they will bring for discussion at the coming meeting of National Council of Minimum Wage for 2021. CLC told MoLVT that they would conduct research on living cost of the worker in garment, footwear and textile sector and will bring the result from the proposed research to debate and discuss at the meeting of National Council of Minimum Wage and also expressed that CLC will applying all 7 criteria to determine 2021 minimum wage. The total participant was 46 (male= 30, and female=16). (2). On 5, 12 and 24 July, and 5 August 2020, CLC leader conducted 4 different minimum wage preparatory meetings participated by TU leaders, activists and workers from Sabrina (Cambodia) Garment Manufacturing Corp; Dignity Knitter Limited; Top Summit Garment Inc; Goldfame Star Enterprises (Cambodia) Limitet; Roo Hsing Garment Co.,Ltd; T & K Garment Industry Co.,Ltd; Da Rong Printing & Embroidery Co,.Ltd; E-Garment Co.,Ltd; Man Ou Garment Co., Ltd.- Eco Base Factory Ltd; Din Han Enterprise Co.,Ltd; and APPLE APPAREL (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD. The meeting agreed to use 7 criteria which is determined by ILO for commencing minimum wage in garment, footwear and textile sector for Cambodia. Workers who participated the meeting suggested to MoLVT officials that the 2021 minimum wage should be 250 USD. MoLVT accepted the suggestions from the workers and they expressed that they will bring for discussion at the coming meeting of National Council of Minimum Wage for 2021. The total participant was 106 (male= 66, and female=40). (3) On 7 September 2020, CLC/C.CAWDU leaders conducted a consultative meeting with affiliate federations and GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia in garment, footwear and textile sector throughout Cambodia. The total participant was 9 (male=6, and female=3). CLC leader shared the position paper developed by CLC and consultant. The ILO 7 criteria that contribute in commencing minimum wage outlined specific valid figure on living cost of the workers in garment, footwear and textile sector and other 6 criteria including family situation, inflation rate, productivity, competitiveness of the country, labour market situation, and profitability of the sector. (4) On 9 and 10 September 2020, CLC attended 2 days tripartite negotiation meeting to commence 2021 Minimum Wage in garment, footwear and textile sector in Cambodia. The meeting was held under coordination of National Council of Minimum Wage at MoLVT meeting hall. Participants from MoLVT, National Council of Minimum Wage, Trade Union Confederations, ILO, GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia. Trade Union leader who have a tendency to support the government, they debated to decrease minimum wage 2021 on base of negative impact of COVID-19 pandemic and the decreased purchase orders. CLC leader, Mr. Arth Thorn convinced all participants by doing presentation on the result from doing assessment and position. At the meeting, the National Council on Minimum Wage, chaired by Minister of Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training made decision by increased 2 USD (adding up 2 USD on the existing minimum wage 190 USD, so the 2021 minimum wage is 192 USD and the Minister stated that it shall be effective from the beginning of January 2021. The total participant was 48 (male=39, and female=9).
8 for Social Dialogue: (1) On 7, and 12 July 2020, CLC conducted 2 difference meetings participated by trade union leaders and activists/management from Top Summit, Appl Apparel Co.,Ltd; Da Rong Printing & Embroidery Co,.Ltd or Yuan Da Rong Fong (Cambodia) B Textile Co., Ltd, E-Garment Co., Ltd; Goldfame Star Enterprises (Cambodia) Limitet; and T&K Garment Industry Co.,Ltd; and Dignity Knitter Limited. TU leaders and activists from each factory were aware of tripartite social dialogue and the overview of negotiation process in minimum wage commencement in Cambodia and TU also understood of the difference between bi-partite and tripartite social dialogue. CLC president, Mr. Ath Thorn, shared experience related Social Dialogue through Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) and strategy on how to apply for CBA at the industrial level, and he also recommended that TU leader can exercise their rights by participating in all process of Collective Bargaining (CBA) with employers and he also emphasized that it is kind of bi-partite social dialogue. All participants were aware of the importance of applicable social dialogue through CBA, minimum wage negotiation, and Most Representative Status (MRS). TU leaders, activists/management, and workers understood and had a commitment to mobilizing workers in order to have the biggest percentage of worker-members at the workplace to ensure TU that is the affiliate of C.CAWDU are able to be satisfied and offered an MRS certificate by the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training (MoLVT). All participants agreed together that they will share with all workers at their workplace and make a plan to collect all relevant documents to apply for the MRS. The total participant was 13 (male=6, and female=7). (5) On 24 July 2020, C.CAWDU legal team did follow-up on 1 collective case taking place at Quint Major Industrial Co.,Ltd and also joint reconciliation meeting under coordination of Provincial Department of Labour (PDoLVT) in Kandal Province. Workers proposed 4 demand points, while employer agreed with 2 demand points. For the 2 remaining points which are not agreed by the both sides, PDoLVT decided to reconcile at Arbitration Council (AC) in Phnom Penh. Workers and Employer of company were informed that PDoLVT would send official invitation letter for the next step discussion under coordination of AC next month. The total participant was 9 (all were male). (6) On 30 July 2020, CLC legal team and layers and all the 5 victims attended the hearing to defend worker before the court at the office of First instance in Svay Rieng province. The court made decision and issued an order demanding all 9 perpetrators, who committed a violent to pay compensations to the 5 victims. Court also allowed and provide opportunity to the perpetrators file complain back. Therefore, workers and layer, and legal team of CLC/C.CAWDU are prepared for next hearing if the perpetrators want to have more complaint against the decision of the court. (7) On 14 August 2020, C.CAWDU leader, Mr. Kong Atith had meeting with GMAC and Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training. At the meeting. C.CAWDU had 3 suggestions to GMAC as follows: 1) GMAC has to push factories to apply safe measure principle at workplace amid COVID-19 pandemic, which developed by Ministry of Health (MoH); 2) GMAC should help mobilize financial emergency support from major brands for workers in footwear, textile and garment that are negatively affected by COVID-19 and 3) C.CAWDU made suggestion to MoLVT to have tight inspection at the industrial lever to make sure that they genuinely apply all COVID-19 interventions principle at workplace. GMAC informed C.CAWDU that the government of Germany already provided financial support for workers but the fund was provided through the government of Cambodia and the fund is from the major brands sourcing in Germany. The total participant was 9 (male=6, female=3). (8) On 18 July, and 14 August 2020, C.CAWDU conducted 2 different meetings participated by TU leaders, activists/managements, and workers from 6 factories as well as Sabrina (Cambodia) Garment Manufacturing Corp; Tien Sung Garment (Cambodia) Co.,Ltd; Dignity Knitter Limited.Sangwoo (Cambodia) Co., Ltd; CHU HSING GARMENT (CAMBODIA) CO.,LTD; APPLE APPAREL (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD. The meeting was held near the factory. C.CAWDU’s President Mr. Kong Atith promoted the awareness on benefits that all workers are entitled due to factory closure and the benefit related to social protection that employers shall be responsible for. The benefits that were shared by Mr. Kong Atith is: National Social Security Fund (NSSF) pay for health insurance for all workers, TU legitimately have rights to organize and have full rights to mobilize member at the workplace without any restriction from the employer, Employers have to pay compensation on the base of contract (UDC/FDC) aligned with the Labour law of Cambodia. The meeting gave an opportunity for all participant to have a recommendation on the Labour Law, and the collected significant recommendations from the participants such as: - The government of Cambodia intentionally decreased benefit for the night work shift and workers recommended that C.CAWDU and CLC not participate in any proposed meeting by the government to adjust the law that will harm the benefit of workers who are working at night time. - All trade union leaders and activists who participated in the meeting asked C.CAWDU and CLC to boycott and to issue a letter or joint letter to express our disappointed concerning the decreased benefit committed by the government of Cambodia C.CAWDU gathered all recommendations and pledged to have a discussion with all affiliates to advocate with the government in order to promote and protect all legitimate interests for workers in the garment, footwear, and textile sector. The total participant was 83 (male= 41, female=42).
